comments.commentBody:
The real story is that the TSA is fundamentally ineffective. Security experts pretty much agree that while they are inspecting shoes a determined, smart terrorist could do some real damage.

As others have pointed out, the TSA is very much like a drunk looking for his keys underneath a street lamp. It's the easiest place to look because there is light there. There are also no keys.

This story became the journalistic equivalent to yelling "fire" in a crowded room. I had just traveled 5000 miles last week, on one-way tickets, and saw none of this. (And if anyone would see this, I would as I was marked for secondary security search every flight for eight years after 9/11). I had to google to find out when these new screening methods went in place. (October, just so you know.) Personally, I believe it was to get the attention away from Congress, where Republicans had blocked the extension of unemployment benefits (no money for that, they said) and fought for tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires. All the while we're getting the same stories (the bladder cancer patient and spilled urine, the mastectomy victim removing her prosthetic, the young boy with his shirt taken off, a poodle being patted down because it was wearing a sweater). I'm a member of the media and I'm embarrassed for my industry.

The real rage should be directed at $5.00 pillows, ultra cramped seats that are not healthful, grossly overpriced wine, grossly overpriced and poor meals on "longer" flights, nothing on shorter flights except inedible and overpriced snacks, surly flight attendants, not sufficient rest rooms (and with split-seat toilets that women always have to clean before use as the men dribble), aisles that are too narrow, bad air (usually grossly overheated)and either no entertainment or, increasing, grossly overpriced films for purchase. But this will continue unless Americans and other passengers complain. Loudly. And to gt to our elected officials to regulate this far more effectively. Why should we get thrombosis due to tiny seats and long flights and no space to move around? This is a health issue. As is the poor nutrition. etc.

This, is an outstanding story, and you, Mr. Segal, should be commended for having the chutzpah to actually appear on this "pyscho's" doorstep for an interview.  Oh, how I wish I were a fly on that wall!  Investigative journalism at its finest.  Glad to see the New York Times continually doing the kind of reporting we sorely need.

Mr. Segal, I happily join the large choir of those praising your piece as a truly top-flight example of hard-hitting investigative journalism at its finest.

Perhaps more important is that you must have placed yourself at some risk -- and must have known you might be wading into a very dangerous snake pit. Yes, you have the NYT behind you, which surely must give even this "walking human IED" pause. Of course, I jope I'm wrong about any danger to you -- maybe this jerk immediately smelled the coffee, at least in your case.

The failures on the parts of eBay and Citibank are absolutely appalling. As for law enforcement, we have to remember two factors that restrict them: (1.) for criminal charges, a police have to build a case at least minimally acceptable to the prosecutor's office, given tight budget all around, even in the best of economic times; and, (2.)the burden of proof, perhaps unfortunately, is the responsibility of the accuser, in this case, ultimately, Ms. Rodriguez (via convincing the police, etc.).

Several here have expressed the sentiment (with which I agree) that it sure would be nice to strip him of his U.S. citizenship and deport him back to Russia. While I'm not a lawyer, as I understand it, if a person has obtained his citizenship legally and didn't obtain it using false pretenses, I don't think he *can* be so treated. If you have a passport, read the bit in it about giving up or losing your citizenship -- it's rare. Ditto (I think) if he has some other kind of visa or a green card. His despicable behavior reported here does not involve his immigration status. (Just think of all the ruckus about illegal aliens along our southern border; many people seem not to realize that "illegal entry" doesn't equate to *criminal* entry -- it's a *civil* offense. Maybe it SHOULD be criminal, but it's not, for now anyway.)

Though I can't actually condone any criminal in itself retaliation against this thug, I wouldn't exactly lose any sleep were I to read here in the NYT later that this guy messed with the wrong person -- a powerful politician or businessperson, maybe. Or maybe the NYPD's Chief's wife! Or a mafia don's. El Jerko is likely too smart for that, though; I doubt he'd ever try to run a scam on the First Lady, for instance.

Again -- what a tremendous piece of work. I realize the news media is under enormous financial pressure, but it surely would be nice to see more pieces like this: hard-hitting news about stuff that affects us, The Little People.

Two thumbs up -- a hundred times over!

Coverage of the 'imbroglio' on scanning was exactly like the coverage of the issues in the last election.  Short on facts, low on reliability, and everyone ganging up on the administration when it was doing what it was supposed to be doing.  Whether it was needed or not, was not discussed, seemingly deemed unimportant.  The NY Times was as bad as the rest.  Is there a problem when you have to take everything out of your pockets and then still get groped if something lights up on the screen?  Yes.  How about finding out why they don't fix that, or felt that these things were ready for prime time!  Oh,sorry, that'd be called investigative reporting, something that seems to be vanishing from the landscape.

The letter to Dr. John Holdren questioning the safety of backscatter technology

http://www.npr.org...

And a recent update confirming their safety concern is still unresolved.
http://softwareobjects.net...
Why are you feeding this story?
No matter how you cut it the terrorists amongst us have won yet another round.

This struck me last week as an excellent example of the news media hyping something -- anything! -- to fill up the 24 hour news cycle. While the media were claiming this was a huge issue, polls were showing that 80+ percent of Americans were fine with the new technologies and procedures.  But, as with the Tea Party, the MSM focused on the 15%, not the 80% (5% undecided :-) )

Perhaps the most vocal outcry came from those with nothing in the game.  The TSA screening was only accessible to ticketed passengers who had paid hundreds of dollars, were on their way home for the holidays with family and trusted the TSA to provide them with security from their fellow passengers.  Perhaps the bonds of family, security and finances transcend the perceived anger of the 'masses' whipped up by the media story lines.  Perhaps the recent elections would have been a more civil discourse if voters had to make a reservation and pay for a ticket to get to voting booth.  Indeed, talk is cheap.

To me, the interesting thing is what will continue to happen. I have felt very violated as a result of these recent pat downs.
As a physician, I refuse the machines due to the unknown monitoring, calibration and longterm effects of the radiation emitted not being determined yet.
So I will be driving on all trips less than 500 miles. If there are only 20,000 people like me who spent say a minimum of $1000 a year travelling, that is a $20 million loss to the airlines. It probably will be a lot more, as ndividuals and companies rethink their polices, in light of these new TSA policies.
I think over time the economic effect of these invasions of privacy by an agency, TSA, that obviously did not really consider what it is doing, will be noticed.
As an aside, having had the untrained, underpaid, and surly TSA agents stroke and squeeze my body does make me realize how totalitarian regimes reach to the bottom (no pun intended) to enforce invasive policies. I now see how facism operates.

Nonesense. Most people chose to go through the system without protesting, which does not mean the outrage is not there, only that sensible, "sane" people chose not to get arrested or delayed, and didn't want to disrupt the schedule for thousands of fellow-travelers. Lack of pointless Euro-style strikes or protests means nothing. Having to risk getting your whatsis grabbed by a TSA bureaucrat in order to visit Grandma is still a problem.

It appears the reporters are embarrassed by the fact that the news doesn't always happen as quickly and vividly as they need it to happen.

TSA's wild overstepping is a story. It's not a flashy story; it's a nerd story of some significance. This is not helpful to panting byline-chasers with a news cycle to feed. So the byline-chasers get petulant and blame the story for not successfully aiding them in their careers.

I used to think better of the Times, but I know too many people now who write for it, and I'm not surprised by the reportorial reaction.
Given how easy he was to find and his behavior, I'm surprised no one's showed up at his house before with a baseball bat in tow....

I'm glad this received the attention it did and am saddened the National Opt-Out Day wasn't bigger.

Note to fellow Americans: Our liberties are like a handful of sand. Once they slip between your fingers, they're very difficult to get back.

Here's a simple answer, maybe it's because of majority of the people who are concerned about the issue simply didn't fly home this Thanksgiving. I personally fall into that camp, but took a train instead of a plane. I'm sure there are plenty of people who are concerned (just because 60% of people think something is alright doesn't make it true) that drove home or took another method of transportation. Seems to be the simplest answer.

As the first comment pointed out, the reason there wasn't a lot of protest might have been that there wasn't anything to protest. I read several accounts online that the TSA simply wasn't using the scanners or the pat-downs, but I never saw mention of that one way or another in any of the news accounts. Personally, I think that's an important par of the story. The fact still remains that there is a lot of skepticism about the safety and validity of the scanners and the outrage about the pat-downs is moslty because there isn't any other alternative for those fearing for their health and privacy.

David: Is there a list of airports who had the scanners in use on the day before Thanksgiving?

More non-journalism from Mr. Carr.  Disappointing.  If the TSA DIDN'T USE the equipment this weekend, would that be a story worthy of coming down from the media-pundit mountaintop to actually report on?  Because, anecdotally, I believe that's what happened.  But then I can't be sure of what was happening throughout the system, because I'm not the New York Times -- and apparently, neither is this.  Not anymore.

On the eve of the busiest travel day of the year, TV pundits turned into government shills. Chris Matthews pontificated that if we showed up to protest, opt-out of the Rapiscan or otherwise exercise our Fourth Amendment rights, we would be inconveniencing others and making them miss out on Grandma's dinner.

This article did not mention that the TSA procedures may not only be violating the Fourth Amendment, but also the Americans with Disabilities Act. People with prostheses or any kind of metal in their bodies, as well as those in wheelchairs, will be forced to undergo the enhanced patdowns.

The corporate-owned mainstream media abandoned the story the minute the government propaganda machine swung into action.

This seller is a fool and completely misunderstands the difference between the "crazy eddie" seller and the scammer. This guy is also the product of his culture and the selling techniques, including lying, substitution of genuine products with replica merchandise and customer harassment are probably normative behavior in his part of the world. While this may sound racist and certainly culture biased, it's a fact of life. I live in SEA and business practices here are, well, bordering on the unsavory to say the least and crooked at best but it's caveat emptor here, squared.

All cultures have honest and dishonest merchants. In some cultures what is a normal bargaining or business tactic may seem dishonest or unethical to the outsider. The truly dishonest merchants are not interested in the concept of 'customer satisfaction' which is probably a Western or even American conceit. A Chinese manufacturer substitutes melamine into milk to add bulk and it's about his profit, not about anything else.

Unfortunately, on the internet which is a blank slate, there is no way to identify the cultural proclivities of the seller. You must rely on the inherent honesty of the system and take whatever safeguards are afforded to you. I have bought from ebay quite a few times and from amazon more than a few times and my experiences have been uniformly satisfactory. It is really up to those hosting the seller to insure they are honest and it's up to the buyer to be proactive and search for criticism of the seller and then make an informed decision.

Just because there weren't massive protests at airports does not mean that people are pleased with the new screening measures, nor that people believe that a good balance has been struck between security and individual rights. It would be very unlikely that overt protests would occur at airports. People know that screening agents take any sort of non-routine comment or action at the check-in line very seriously. Overt protests would almost certainly get one removed for questioning... which could involve missing one's flight, and missing Thanksgiving dinner with family. I doubt many fliers are willing to make such a sacrifice, even if they are displeased with TSA procedures.

Not unlike the preacher in Florida who got the media's rapt attention by threatening to burn the Koran.  It isn't a story at all until a media that is driven by the freakish discovers it.  Nobody cares or cared.  It is time the media remembered it is there to report the news not make it.

Not quite a non-story. My experiences of international travel last week just as the story broke but before thanksgiving led me to think that this was an important issue that people should take seriously. Several videos have confirmed for me that the TSA is itself as much of a problem as that which it was designed to address. That doesn't mean that the new scanners are the issue, maybe just the organization : http://www.youtube.com...

What Google should do is allow side by side comparison of its search results to its search results with negative feedback about the website in question. For instance if three sites come up and two are good and the third is this man's site then his would rank third in the subjective rank and warn people about his site. People need to be smarter and not just go with a website in a vacuum. They should dig deeper. That would shut down frauds like this man.
